message: http://ethanschoonover.com/solarized
That looks great. Thanks for the link!
Switched to it this morning. Recommend it.
Not for my tired eyes, but very nice presentation
Tried it yesterday but did not work with python & coffeescript syntax. Back to darkblue
that's awesome. looks like a lot of thought went into it
Looks good, but I <3 Monokai
got this 'E121: Undefined variable: w:solarized_style' error with the togglebackg function. any idea?
I love the idea of solarised, I'm just not a fan of that particular green or the overabundance of blue and orange, I'll stick with jellybeans for now
Wow, i just switched, thanks!
I switched to solarized too.  It looked awful at first, but then I got used to it
using the dark version with vim
only issue I have is that `set listchars=` is too dark to be visible
if anyone have any hints how to resolve that it would be appreciated
Looks beautiful. Just about to install it and see if it'll replace molokai as my default.
I like it, it's nice. The blue-green is soothing, but not sure it'll replace molokai. Will try it at work tomorrow an see how it goes.
@amiamirul take a look on this: https://github.com/altercation/vim-colors-solarized/issues#issue/1
@gnuget thnx. works for me
Anybody using this with Terminal.app? Does the color of cursor change depending on selected text like what it does on MacVim?
Is there a way to change light/dark scheme on the fly? ":set background=dark" and ":colorscheme solarized" keeps the light theme for me.
@passy same for me but let g:solarized_style="dark" works
@dag well spotted! I was going to submit an issue for that, but someone had already done it: https://github.com/altercation/vim-colors-solarized/issues#issue/1
I have the same issue with set listchars=.  I use this to highlight tabs in .py source files.
background is too blue for me. Love the other colours though.
@asksol hey he fixed the listchars problem in the latest git build
Nice color scheme, the latest from github makes it much more usable, thx for pointing that out @kevin1024
@kevin1024: Yeah, it's much better now :)
Can someone post a screenshot of their iTerm2 with light Solarize? Would like an 'ls -a' that shows colors used for executables, linked files, folders and text files. Thanks!
@passy Are you looking for ":set background=light" perhaps?
First few times I used Solarized I hated it, but now it's the default. Very pretty and unobtrusive.
I like the idea of this theme, but it just doesn't sit well with me for 10+ hours a day
now I just need to calibrate my external monitors. They make the blue very greenish... Having a window span both the laptop lcd and the external makes it obvious how bad it is.
Very cool, digging this a lot. Nice change of pace from a black background.
In gvim everything looks good, but in the terminal I'm always getting the light background.
@kennyparnell `:let g:solarized_style="dark"` then `:colo solarized` again. I believe a fix for this is either in the github repo or coming soon.
Do you have trouble setting the Xresources so tha things look good on terminal VIM?
@seesharp this is mine with the dark one: http://imgur.com/17XwG
@seesharp try going to Edit Current Session -> Text and uncheck "Draw bold text in bright colors"
the iTerm2 one doesn't have the bright colors for some reason

@nuclearsandwich Thanks, but still no luck. My TERM is xterm-256color and in my vimrc I have:
call pathogen#runtime_append_all_bundles()

    set background=dark
    let g:solarized_underline=0
    let g:solarized_style="dark"
    colorscheme solarized

@kennyparnell I just pulled the latest from the git repo. If you `set background=dark` *after* `colortheme solarized` it now works. Additionally if you want to switch back and forth you can change the value of background and it will auto update. Sorry, my info was stale.

i use it with terminal version of vim. and i also change my .Xdefaults according to solarized. the problem is my terminal. the fonts colors are too dark and it's hard to see what i type in a terminal. anyone else got this issue?

I couldn't get it to work with terminal, well I just gave up after a while :)  works well in mvim though, but there is a light shade of blue for some keywords that is hard to read...(with the dark background)
I've got no luck with Solarized in Terminal.app either. MacVim looks great though...
You also need to use Solarized scheme for Terminal.app in order to have Vim in Terminal displays color correctly.

Unfortunately, if you want the colorscheme to work in terminal app you will have to install SIMBL and the terminal colors plugin. They have details up in this readme https://github.com/altercation/solarized/blob/master/osx-terminal.app-colors-solarized/README.md
Or you can use iTerm2 but you do need to have Xcode installed for it to work.
+1 for iTerm2
iTerm2 is the best :)

After all the recommendations for iTerm2 I decided to give it a try, but things are off -- most noticeable the status bar color: http://i.imgur.com/Yz9h8.png (terminal.app on the left, iterm on the right). Anyone else have similar problems?
I had this problem yesterday

@csexton I'm not too concerned about the status bar, it's the dark rectangles around the coloured letters that I noticed in iTerm2. I had to change the reported terminal type to 'xterm-256color' in my preferences to get the boxes to go away.
@csexton Do you have xcode installed?  I had some issues with iTerm2 and xterm-256color mode before I got Xcode installed on this new computer.  There's some dependencies there apparently.

I'm loving this theme, but having some issues getting it to work when running vim from the terminal (it works in MacVim beautifully). I am using iTerm2 with the imported solarized theme, but when running vim I'm having the following problem: http://i.imgur.com/P6fd7.png (dark), http://i.imgur.com/YIegQ.png (light). Anyone solved a similar problem?
@supjeff I do have xcode installed, and set the term to report itself as 'xterm-256color' not sure on this one.

I found a solution for my problem above incase anyone experiences the same issues: From the iTerm2 preferences window, select the terminal tab for your current profile and choose xterm-256color for the "Report Terminal Type" option under the "Terminal Emulation" section. I unknowingly had it set to xterm (which I think is the default).
